item.title: The Care and Feeding of a Toothbrush
item.description:
There are regular toothbrushes, electric toothbrushes, and even toothbrushes that give little beeps when they think you have had enough. But they all have one thing in common—GERMS. We get two common questions in our dental office about germs on toothbrushes.

After I am sick, what can I do to get the toothbrush clean so I don't get sick again?

The easy answer—Don't worry about boiling it, soaking it in soap and water, or any of the other tricks you hear about or read online. Unless you are on a very tight budget, after you have been sick, throw the thing out and get a new toothbrush! We give our patients a free toothbrush after every cleaning.

And a related question: Is it true that germs on my toothbrush can make me sick? And if so, can I store it some way that I can decrease the number of germs on it?

Yes, they can make you sick, but it is very unlikely. Some tips: The best way to keep your toothbrush free from germs is to make sure it is rinsed after each use. Let it dry thoroughly, and keep it as far away from the toilet as possible to avoid spray from flushing. Make sure to set it upright, so it is off of the counter. Enclosing the toothbrush in a toothbrush case is not a good idea, because germs thrive in the humidity. If you must keep it in a case, thoroughly dry it out with a paper towel before placing it in the case. Make sure your toothbrush does not touch anyone else's toothbrush (Even if you are married!). Most important of all, though, is get a new toothbrush regularly!

Follow these tips, and you can brush your teeth with confidence once again!

Tags: 
dental office
toothbrush
electric toothbrush
germs
cleanings
item.dc:creator: Dr. Inge

item.title: When the Dragons are Upon Us
item.description:
"Fairy tales are more than true: not because they tell us that dragons exist, but because they tell us that dragons can be beaten." Neil Gaiman

There are many dragons when it comes to dental health. There is gum disease, there is tooth decay, there is oral cancer, there is malocclusion, there are abscesses, tumors, fractured teeth, missing teeth, and the list goes on and on. A lot of dentists don't think of themselves as dragon killers. But we are. That is the challenge, and it has to be admitted, the fun of dentistry. We spend our days trying to help our patients slay their dental dragons.

The problem we frequently face, though, is many people don't believe in dragons. Or, what may be worse, they don't realize that dragons are chewing on them until it is too late.

That is why dentistry has historically led the field in medicine when it comes to prevention and education. It's not just that dragons can be beaten. It's that with a little prevention they usually can be kept out of the country to begin with. And if one does slip in, they can be beaten fairly easily if caught early enough.

So we at Inge Dental encourage all our patients to come in twice a year for routine cleanings, exams, fluoride treatments and x-rays if they are needed. To slay your dragons, contact us to make an appointment for a cleaning and exam today!

Dragons can be beaten.

Tags: 
dental health
gum disease
tooth decay
oral cancer
cleanings
fluoride treatments

item.title: Teeth Cleaning
item.description:
Tags: 
cleanings
item.dc:creator: Dr. Inge

item.title: Four things a cleaning and exam every six months can save you:
item.description:
1. Save you time: The time it takes for two cleanings and exams every year is a fraction of the time it takes for major dental work required because of allowing a small problem become a larger one. In this fast paced society time is valuable. Most major work (crowns, root canals, dentures, and such) require anywhere from two to four visits, each requiring an hour or more. A simple 40 minute cleaning and exam can prevent this.
  2. Save you expense: The expense of two cleanings and exams per year is a fraction of the expense for major dental work due to neglect. It is an investment that really pays off.
  3. Save you from pain: Catching things early with two cleanings and exams per year can save you from serious pain—Toothaches are no fun!
  4. Save your teeth: catching things early with two cleanings and exams per year can save your teeth—Losing teeth is no fun!

So make a cleaning and exam every six months your routine, and SAVE!

Tags: 
cleanings
dental cleanings
dental hygienist
